Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 611710: Educational Support Services
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: CSC agreed to pay $81 million to resolve a dispute with the Maryland Department of Health concerning its performance on an information technology contract.
Agency: Maryland Attorney General
Info Source: http://www.marylandattorneygeneral.gov/press/2018/020918.pdf

Description: Electronic Data Systems agreed to pay $3.4 million to resolve an investigation into whether the company's insurance subsidiary overcharged the state for managing its Medicaid program.
Agency: Travis County (TX) District Attorney
Info Source: Contractor to pay state $3.4 million; EDS resolves inquiry into possible Medicaid overcharges but doesn't admit to any wrongdoing, Austin American-Statesman, June 7, 2001 (via Nexis).

Agency: U.S. Attorney-Northern District of Alabama
Info Source: Computer Sciences Pays $1.275 Million to Settle False Reimbursement Claim, US Fed News, September 28, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: Omaha Property and Casualty Company and Electronic Data Systems Incorporated agreed to pay a total of $2,480,000 to settle allegations that they paid flood insurance losses knowing that those losses were not covered by National Flood Insurance Program policies that were properly in place at the time of the loss. The announcement did not indicae how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally between them.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-District of Maryland
Info Source: OMAHA PROPERTY AND CASUALTY, EDS AGREE TO PAY $2.48 MILLION TO SETTLE NATIONAL FLOOD INSURANCE OVERPAYMENT CLAIM, US Fed News, August 3, 2007 (via Nexis).
